fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Martín H. Escardó
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: https://www.cs.bham.ac.uk/~mhe/

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Standard abbreviation: mhe.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Zoo of notions of (im)predicativity
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: notes from a talk by Escardó, with some additions by Ayberk Tosun

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Predicativity in the sense of Russell's ramified type theory
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Martín H. Escardó's lab lunch talk

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Quantification over all sets of a given type gives a set of the next type.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Impredicativity in the sense of Russell’s Reducibility Axiom
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: pp. 241-244 of Mathematical Logic based on the Theory of Types

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The Axiom of Reducibility states that any truth function (i.e. propositional function) can be expressed by a formally equivalent predicative truth function.
This is where the term “predicative” originates from as it says propositional functions can be reduced to predicates.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Impredicativity in the sense of System F
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Martín H. Escardó's lab lunch talk

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Quantification over all types in the first universe gives a type in the first universe.
This form of impredicativity is also present in the Calculus of Constructions and the Calculus of Inductive Constructions.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Impredicativity in the sense of topos logic

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Forming powersets is allowed.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Predicativity in the sense of Aczel's CZF

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Forming powersets is not allowed.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Predicativity in the sense of MLTT

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Quantification over the types in one universe gives a type in the next universe.
This is similar to axt-005Z.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Predicativity in the sense of HoTT/UF

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: This is the same as axt-0062 since HoTT/UF is a system extending a particular MLTT with univalence and so-called higher-inductive types.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Impredicativity in the sense of HoTT/UF

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Voevodsky’s propositional resizing axiom is assumed. There are several forms of this axiom of varying strengths but they are all variations of the statement that propositional types quantifying over other types are small.
This seems to be somewhat similar to axt-0067.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Predicativity in the sense of Feferman

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Any theory that has the strength of the Feferman-Schütte ordinal or above is deemed to be impredicative.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Pataraia's Lemma implies propositional resizing
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Theorem 52 of de Jong and Escardó

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: If Pataraia's Lemma holds (for ( \mathcal {U} \sqcup \mathcal {V} ^+, \mathcal {V} , \mathcal {V} )-dcpos) then ( \mathcal {U} , \mathcal {V} )-propositional resizing holds.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: Suppose Pataraia's Lemma holds for ( \mathcal {U} \sqcup \mathcal {V} ^+, \mathcal {V} , \mathcal {V} )-dcpos and let P : \Omega _{ \mathcal {U} }. Consider the lifting dcpo \mathcal {L}_{ \mathcal {V} }( P ). By Lemma 45, it suffices to show that \mathcal {L}_{ \mathcal {V} }( P ) has a maximal element Q : \Omega _{ \mathcal {V} }. By Pataraia's Lemma, there must be a greatest monotone inflationary endofunction g : \mathcal {L}_{ \mathcal {V} }( P ) \to \mathcal {L}_{ \mathcal {V} }( P ) for the dcpo \mathcal {L}_{ \mathcal {V} }( P ). One can then show that g(0) : \Omega _{ \mathcal {V} } is a maximal element of \mathcal {L}_{ \mathcal {V} }( P ). Let Q : \Omega _{ \mathcal {V} } with g(0) \sqsubseteq Q. We have to show Q \sqsubseteq g(0) to conclude that g(0) is a maximal element. Consider the closed nucleus \mathbf {c}( Q ), which must satisfy \mathbf {c}( Q ) \sqsubseteq g since g is the greatest element of the poset of monotone and inflationary endofunctions. We therefore have Q = \mathbf {c}( 0 ) \sqsubseteq g(0).

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Pataraia's Lemma
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Definition 51 of de Jong and Escardó

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Pataraia's Lemma says that every \mathcal {W}-dcpo with carrier in universe \mathcal {U} and order taking values in \mathcal {V} has a greatest monotone inflationary endofunction.

fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Thm. 48 of de Jong and Escardó

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathcal {U} and \mathcal {V} be two universes. If \mathsf {ZornsLemma}( \mathcal {U} \sqcup \mathcal {V} ^{+} , \mathcal {V} , \mathcal {V} ) holds then \mathsf {PropositionalResizing}( \mathcal {U} , \mathcal {V} ) holds.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Zorn's Lemma in UF
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Defn. 47 of de Jong and Escardó

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathcal {U}, \mathcal {V}, and \mathcal {W} be universes. Zorn’s Lemma at ( \mathcal {U} , \mathcal {V} , \mathcal {W} ) asserts that every pointed ( \mathcal {U} , \mathcal {V} , \mathcal {W} )-dcpo has a maximal element.
This is sometimes denoted \mathsf {ZornsLemma}( \mathcal {U} , \mathcal {V} , \mathcal {W} ).

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Being 𝓥-small
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Defn. 1 from de Jong and Escardó

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathcal {U} and \mathcal {V} be two universes. A type X : \mathcal {U} is called \mathcal {V}-small if it has a copy in universe \mathcal {V}, which is to say \mathsf {hasSize}( X , \mathcal {V} ) \vcentcolon \equiv \sum _{ Y \ : \ \mathcal {V} } X \simeq Y .

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: The type of ¬¬-stable propositions
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Defn 2.iii of de Jong and Escardó

fr:mainmatter.fr:p:
Let \mathcal {U} be a universe. The type of 
eg 
eg-stable propositions at universe \mathcal {U} is defined as: \Omega ^{ 
eg 
eg }_{ \mathcal {U} } \vcentcolon \equiv \sum _{ P \ : \ \Omega _{ \mathcal {U} } } \mathsf {isNotNotStable}( P )

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: The Ω (𝓤, 𝓥)-resizing axiom
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Defn 2.ii from de Jong and Escardó

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathcal {U} and \mathcal {V} be two universes. The \Omega ( \mathcal {U} , \mathcal {V} )-resizing axiom says that the type \Omega _{ \mathcal {U} } is \mathcal {V}-small.

A \mathcal {V}-dcpo being pseudocontinuous is the same thing as it having a specified continuity datum, but with the specified existence requirement in the notion of continuity datum relaxed to requirement of mere existence.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Extensional spectral basis for a locale

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: An extensional spectral basis (B, \beta ) for a \mathcal {W}-locale is an intensional spectral basis that is extensional.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Intensional spectral basis for a locale

fr:mainmatter.fr:p:
An intensional spectral basis for a \mathcal {W}-locale X is an intensional basis (B, \beta ) for the frame \mathcal {O}( X ) (considered as a \mathcal {W}-dcpo) that satisfies the following two conditions
For every b : B, \beta (b) is a compact open of X.
The basis (B, \beta ) is closed under finite meets. This is to say that it satisfies the following conditions.
It contains the empty meet: \exists t : B. \ \mathsf {isTop}( \beta (t)).
It is closed under binary meets: \forall b_1, b_2 : B. \ \exists b_3 : B \ \beta (b_3) \ \text {is the glb of} \ \{ \beta (b_2), \beta (b_3) \} .

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Compact open of a locale in UF
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Defn. 3.5 of Tosun and Escardó

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let X be a ( \mathcal {U} , \mathcal {V} , \mathcal {W} )-locale. An open U : \mathcal {O}( X ) is called compact if the principal filter on U is inaccessible by joins of directed \mathcal {W}-families.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Continuous map of data types
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: 2nd paragraph of Sec. 3.1 of the Barbados notes

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A function f : \mathtt {a} \to \mathtt {b} of data types is called continuous if is definable Haskell.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Continuous map of spaces
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: 1st paragraph of Sec. 3.7 of the Barbados notes

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let X and Y be two spaces with environments \mathtt { a } and \mathtt { b } respectively. A function \varphi : X \to Y is continuous if there exists a continuous function of data types f : \mathtt { a } \to \mathtt { b } such that \forall x \in X. \ \varphi (x) = f(x).

The initial frame at universe \mathcal {U} in UF is the type \Omega _{ \mathcal {U} } viewed as a ( \mathcal {U} ^+, \mathcal {U} , \mathcal {U} )-frame as follows:
Order: P \le Q \vcentcolon \equiv P \Rightarrow Q.
Top element: \mathbf {1} \vcentcolon \equiv \top _{ \mathcal {U} } .
Meet: P \wedge Q \vcentcolon \equiv P \times Q.
Arbitrary join: \left ( \bigvee _{i : I} P_i \right ) \vcentcolon \equiv \exists k : I. \ P_k .

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Not-not-separated type
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: https://www.cs.bham.ac.uk//~mhe/TypeTopology/UF.DiscreteAndSeparated.html#5439

fr:mainmatter.fr:p:
A type X is called 
eg 
eg-separated if x = y is a 
eg 
eg-stable type for every x, y : X.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Not-not-stable type
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: https://www.cs.bham.ac.uk/~mhe/TypeTopology/MLTT.Negation.html#2342

fr:mainmatter.fr:p:
A type X is called 
eg 
eg-stable if 
eg 
eg A 	o A.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Space
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: 1st paragraph of Sec. 3.5 of the Barbados notes

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A space is a subset X \subseteq \mathtt {a} of inhabitants of a Haskell data type \mathtt {a}.

A ( \mathcal {U} , \mathcal {V} , \mathcal {W} )-locale X is called spectral if it satisfies the following three conditions.
It is a compact locale (i.e. the empty meet is compact).
The meet of two compact opens is compact.
For every U : \mathcal {O}( X ), there exists a directed \mathcal {W}-family (K_U, \kappa _U) that satisfies the following conditions.
(K_U, \kappa _U) is directed.
U = \bigvee _{k : K_U} \kappa _U(k).
It consists of compact opens i.e. \forall k : K_U. \ \mathsf {isCompact}( \kappa _{U}(k) ).

A ( \mathcal {U} , \mathcal {V} , \mathcal {W} )-locale X is called spectral if it satisfies the following three conditions.
It is a compact locale (i.e. the empty meet is compact).
The meet of two compact opens is compact.
For every U : \mathcal {O}( X ), there exists a directed \mathcal {W}-family (K_U, \kappa _U) that satisfies the following conditions.
(K_U, \kappa _U) is directed.
U = \bigvee _{k : K_U} \kappa _U(k).
It consists of compact opens i.e. \forall k : K_U. \ \mathsf {isCompact}( \kappa _{U}(k) ).

Notice the relationship of the third condition here to pseudocontinuity. If we formulate a notion of “pseudoalgebraicity” i.e. the analogue of pseudocontinuity for algebraicity, we could use that to avoid the repetition here because they are exactly the same thing. This is not good for presentation purposes (as for as locale theory is concerned), however, so it should probably be recorded as an equivalence.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Intensional spectral basis for a locale

fr:mainmatter.fr:p:
An intensional spectral basis for a \mathcal {W}-locale X is an intensional basis (B, \beta ) for the frame \mathcal {O}( X ) (considered as a \mathcal {W}-dcpo) that satisfies the following two conditions
For every b : B, \beta (b) is a compact open of X.
The basis (B, \beta ) is closed under finite meets. This is to say that it satisfies the following conditions.
It contains the empty meet: \exists t : B. \ \mathsf {isTop}( \beta (t)).
It is closed under binary meets: \forall b_1, b_2 : B. \ \exists b_3 : B \ \beta (b_3) \ \text {is the glb of} \ \{ \beta (b_2), \beta (b_3) \} .

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Extensional spectral basis for a locale

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: An extensional spectral basis (B, \beta ) for a \mathcal {W}-locale is an intensional spectral basis that is extensional.

A ( \mathcal {U} , \mathcal {V} , \mathcal {W} )-locale X is called zero-dimensional if it satisfies the following condition: for every U : \mathcal {O}( X ), there exists a directed \mathcal {W}-family (K_U, \kappa _U) that satisfies the following conditions.
(K_U, \kappa _U) is directed.
U = \bigvee _{k : K_U} \kappa _U(k).
It consists of clopens i.e. \forall k : K_U. \ \mathsf {isClopen}( \kappa _{U}(k)).

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: The Baire space
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: 1st paragraph of Sec. 3.6 of the Barbados notes

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The Baire space is the subset of the \mathtt {Baire} data type in Haskell consisting of the strict total functions.

A ( \mathcal {U} , \mathcal {V} , \mathcal {W} )-locale X is called zero-dimensional if it satisfies the following condition: for every U : \mathcal {O}( X ), there exists a directed \mathcal {W}-family (K_U, \kappa _U) that satisfies the following conditions.
(K_U, \kappa _U) is directed.
U = \bigvee _{k : K_U} \kappa _U(k).
It consists of clopens i.e. \forall k : K_U. \ \mathsf {isClopen}( \kappa _{U}(k)).

In Tom de Jong's thesis and his Agda formalization of domain theory, the term “structurally continuous” is used to mean a \mathcal {V}-dcpo D equipped with a function giving, for every x : D, a small directed family of elements way below x, giving x as its join.
In the new terminology, this notion of “structure” involved in the continuity of a dcpo is made explicit by the following notion.

A continuity datum for a \mathcal {V}-dcpo D is a function giving, for every x : D, a specified \mathcal {V}-family (K_x, \kappa _x) on D satisfying the following conditions.
The family (K_x, \kappa _x) is directed.
x = \bigvee ^{ \uparrow }_{k : K_x} \kappa _x(k).
For each k : K_x, \kappa _x(k) \ll x.

Factoring this structure out into a definition of its own obviates the need to have a name for the notion of a “\mathcal {V}-dcpo having a specified continuity datum”, which is what “structurally continuous” means. Even though the equivalence between structurally continuous and “having a specified continuity datum” is completely trivial, we still record this in the following proposition to be able to explicitly refer to this terminological identity.

fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Defn 4.4.1 of de Jong's PhD thesis

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A \mathcal {V}-dcpo D having a specified continuity datum is the same thing as D being structurally continuous.

By replacing the specified existence here with mere existence, we obtain the notion of a continuous \mathcal {V}-dcpo. The terminology for this is unchanged (i.e. is the same as the terminology of Tom de Jong's thesis).
A \mathcal {V}-dcpo is called continuous if there exists a continuity datum for it.

A \mathcal {V}-dcpo is called pseudocontinuous if there is a specified function giving, for every x : D, the mere existence of a \mathcal {V}-family (K_x, \kappa _x) on D satisfying the following conditions.
The family (K_x, \kappa _x) is directed.
x = \bigvee ^{ \uparrow }_{k : K_x} \kappa _x(k).
For each k : K_x, \kappa _x(k) \ll x.

A \mathcal {V}-dcpo being pseudocontinuous is the same thing as it having a specified continuity datum, but with the specified existence requirement in the notion of continuity datum relaxed to requirement of mere existence.

An intensional continuous basis for a \mathcal {V}-dcpo D is an intensional basis (B, \beta ) with the further requirement that for every x : D, the directed \mathcal {V}-family (K_x, \kappa _x) given by the basis satisfies the condition \forall k : K_x. \ \beta ( \kappa _x(k)) \ll x.
An extensional continuous basis for a \mathcal {V}-dcpo D is an intensional continuous basis that is extensional.

An algebraicity datum for a \mathcal {V}-dcpo D is a function giving, for every x : D, a specified \mathcal {V}-family (K_x, \kappa _x) on D that satisfies the following.
The family (K_x, \kappa _x) is directed.
x = \bigvee ^{ \uparrow }_{k : K_x} \kappa _x(k).
For each k : K_x, \kappa _x(k) is compact.

Similar to the case of a continuity datum, we record the terminological identity between a \mathcal {V}-dcpo D being “structurally algebraic” (the terminology from de Jong's thesis) and it having a specified algebraicity datum.
A \mathcal {V}-dcpo D having a specified algebraicity datum is the same thing as D being structurally algebraic.
A \mathcal {V}-dcpo D is called algebraic if there exists an algebraicity datum for it.

Let D be a \mathcal {V}-dcpo and define the type K_x \vcentcolon \equiv \sum _{c : D}{ \mathsf {isCompact}( c ) \times c \sqsubseteq x} of compact elements below a given x : D. The \mathcal {V}-dcpo D is called algebraic if it satisfies the following conditions.
For every x : D, K_x is \mathcal {V}-small.
The \mathcal {V}-family (K_x, \mathsf {pr}_1 ) is directed with supremum x.
An intensional algebraic basis for a \mathcal {V}-dcpo D is an intensional basis (B, \beta ) satisfying \forall b : B. \ \mathsf {isCompact}( \beta (b) ) .
An extensional algebraic basis for a \mathcal {V}-dcpo D is an intensional algebraic basis (B, \beta ) that is extensional.
A \mathcal {V}-dcpo D having a specified algebraicity datum is the same thing as D being structurally algebraic.

Let D be a \mathcal {V}-dcpo and define the type K_x \vcentcolon \equiv \sum _{c : D}{ \mathsf {isCompact}( c ) \times c \sqsubseteq x} of compact elements below a given x : D. The \mathcal {V}-dcpo D is called algebraic if it satisfies the following conditions.
For every x : D, K_x is \mathcal {V}-small.
The \mathcal {V}-family (K_x, \mathsf {pr}_1 ) is directed with supremum x.

An algebraicity datum for a \mathcal {V}-dcpo D is a function giving, for every x : D, a specified \mathcal {V}-family (K_x, \kappa _x) on D that satisfies the following.
The family (K_x, \kappa _x) is directed.
x = \bigvee ^{ \uparrow }_{k : K_x} \kappa _x(k).
For each k : K_x, \kappa _x(k) is compact.

A continuity datum for a \mathcal {V}-dcpo D is a function giving, for every x : D, a specified \mathcal {V}-family (K_x, \kappa _x) on D satisfying the following conditions.
The family (K_x, \kappa _x) is directed.
x = \bigvee ^{ \uparrow }_{k : K_x} \kappa _x(k).
For each k : K_x, \kappa _x(k) \ll x.
A \mathcal {V}-dcpo is called continuous if there exists a continuity datum for it.
An extensional algebraic basis for a \mathcal {V}-dcpo D is an intensional algebraic basis (B, \beta ) that is extensional.
An extensional continuous basis for a \mathcal {V}-dcpo D is an intensional continuous basis that is extensional.
An intensional algebraic basis for a \mathcal {V}-dcpo D is an intensional basis (B, \beta ) satisfying \forall b : B. \ \mathsf {isCompact}( \beta (b) ) .

An intensional continuous basis for a \mathcal {V}-dcpo D is an intensional basis (B, \beta ) with the further requirement that for every x : D, the directed \mathcal {V}-family (K_x, \kappa _x) given by the basis satisfies the condition \forall k : K_x. \ \beta ( \kappa _x(k)) \ll x.

A \mathcal {V}-dcpo is called pseudocontinuous if there is a specified function giving, for every x : D, the mere existence of a \mathcal {V}-family (K_x, \kappa _x) on D satisfying the following conditions.
The family (K_x, \kappa _x) is directed.
x = \bigvee ^{ \uparrow }_{k : K_x} \kappa _x(k).
For each k : K_x, \kappa _x(k) \ll x.
Let D be a \mathcal {V}-dcpo. An intensional basis (B, \beta ) for D is called an extensional basis if \beta is an embedding.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Intrinsically open
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Defn. 2.4 of [Leš2010]

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let ( \mathcal {E} , \Sigma ) be a model of synthetic topology. A subobject U \hookrightarrow X of an object X is called intrinsically open if its characteristic map \chi _{U} : X \to \Omega factors through the Sierpiński object \Sigma.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: \mathcal {V}-dcpo
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Defn. 3.2.7 of ([TdJ], \dagger)

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathcal {V} be a universe. A poset D is a \mathcal {V}-dcpo if the join of of every \mathcal {V}-family on set D exists in D.

Let D be a \mathcal {V}-dcpo. An intensional basis for D is a \mathcal {V}-family (B, \beta ) on D satisfying the condition: for every element x : D, there is a specified directed \mathcal {V}-family (I_x, \iota _x) on the basis index B such that x = \bigvee (I_x, \beta \circ \iota _x).
A locale X is called large and locally small if it is given by a ( \mathcal {U} ^+, \mathcal {U} , \mathcal {U} )-frame.
A \mathcal {V}-dcpo D is called algebraic if there exists an algebraicity datum for it.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Weakly constant map
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Defn 2.13 from KECA

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A function f : X \to Y is called weakly constant if \prod _{x, y : X} f(x) = f(y).

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: On Small Types in Univalent Foundations
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: @article{tdj-mhe-small-types, title = {{On Small Types in Univalent Foundations}}, author = {Tom de Jong and Martín Hötzel Escardó}, date = {2023-05}, url = {https://lmcs.episciences.org/11270}, doi = {10.46298/lmcs-19(2:8)2023}, journal = {{Logical Methods in Computer Science}}, volume = {{Volume 19, Issue 2}}, }

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Frame (type-theoretic)
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Defn. 2.4 from Patch MFPS

fr:mainmatter.fr:p:
A ( \mathcal {U} , \mathcal {V} , \mathcal {W} )-frame L consists of a
a type |L| : \mathcal {U}
a partial order - \le - : |L| \to |L| \to \Omega _{ \mathcal {V} },
a top element \mathbf {1} : |L|,
an operation - \wedge - : |L| \to |L| \to |L| giving the greatest lower bound U \wedge V of any two U, V : |L|.
an operation \bigvee - : \mathsf {Fam} _{ \mathcal {W} }(|L|) \to |L| giving the least upper bound \bigvee _{i : I} U_i of any \mathcal {W}-family \left \{ U_i \right \} _{i : I}.
such that binary meets distribute over arbitrary joins, i.e. U \wedge \bigvee _{i : I} V_i = \bigvee _{i : I} U \wedge V_i for every U : |L| and \mathcal {W}-family \{ V_i \} _{i : I} in |L|.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Patch Locale of a Spectral Locale in Univalent Type Theory
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: % @inproceedings{patch-mfps, title = {{Patch Locale of a Spectral Locale in Univalent Type Theory}}, author = {Ayberk Tosun and Mart\'in H. fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Domain Theory in Constructive and Predicative Univalent Foundations
Predicative Aspects of Order Theory in Univalent Foundations
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: % @InProceedings{tdj-mhe-aspects, title = {Predicative Aspects of Order Theory in Univalent Foundations}, author = {de Jong, Tom and Escardó, Martín H.}, date = {2021}, booktitle = {6th International Conference on Formal Structures for Computation and Deduction (FSCD 2021)}, pages = {8:1--8:18}, series = {Leibniz International Proceedings in Informatics (LIPIcs)}, volume = 195, editor = {Kobayashi, Naoki}, publisher = {Schloss Dagstuhl--Leibniz-Zentrum f\"ur Informatik}, doi = {10.4230/LIPIcs.FSCD.2021.8}, }

fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: % @article{keca, author = {Nicolai Kraus and Mart{\'{\i}}n Escard{\'{o}} and Thierry Coquand and Thorsten Altenkirch}, title = {Notions of Anonymous Existence in Martin-L{\"{o}}f Type Theory}, journal = {Logical Methods in Computer Science}, volume = {13}, number = {1}, year = {2017}, url = {https://doi.org/10.23638/LMCS-13(1:15)2017}, doi = {10.23638/LMCS-13(1:15)2017}, biburl = {https://dblp.org/rec/journals/corr/KrausECA16.bib}, }

fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: % @misc{mhe-mgs2007-slides, author = {Escard\'{o}, Mart\'{i}n H.}, title = {Domain theory and denotational semantics of functional programming}, date = {2007-04-20}, note = {Lecture slides at Midlands Graduate School 2007}, }

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Continuity of Gödel’s System T Definable Functionals via Effectful Forcing
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: % @inproceedings{mhe-effectful-forcing, title = {Continuity of Gödel's System T Definable Functionals via Effectful Forcing}, author = {Escardó, Martín H.}, date = {2013}, doi = {10.1016/j.entcs.2013.09.010}, issn = {1571-0661}, journal = {Electronic Notes in Theoretical Computer Science}, publisher = {Elsevier B.V}, volume = {298}, pages = {119-141}, note = {Proceedings of the Twenty-ninth Conference on the Mathematical Foundations of Programming Semantics, MFPS XXIX}, }

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: On the computational content of the Lawson topology

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Synthetic Topology: of Data Types and Classical Spaces

fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: https://www.cs.bham.ac.uk/~mhe/papers/realpcf.pdf

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Model of synthetic topology
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Defn. 2.4 of [Leš2010]

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A model of synthetic topology is a topos \mathcal {E} with a chosen subobject \Sigma \subseteq \Omega of the subobject classifier, called the Sierpiński object.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: University of Birmingham
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: https://www.birmingham.ac.uk/

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Impredicativity in the sense of System F
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Martín H. Escardó's lab lunch talk

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Quantification over all types in the first universe gives a type in the first universe.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Predicativity in the sense of Russell's ramified type theory
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Martín H. Escardó's lab lunch talk

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Quantification over all sets of a given type gives a set of the next type.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Zoo of notions of (im)predicativity
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: notes from a talk by Escardó, with some additions by Ayberk Tosun

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Predicativity in the sense of Russell's ramified type theory
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Martín H. Escardó's lab lunch talk

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Quantification over all sets of a given type gives a set of the next type.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Impredicativity in the sense of Russell’s Reducibility Axiom
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: pp. 241-244 of Mathematical Logic based on the Theory of Types

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The Axiom of Reducibility states that any truth function (i.e. propositional function) can be expressed by a formally equivalent predicative truth function.
This is where the term “predicative” originates from as it says propositional functions can be reduced to predicates.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Impredicativity in the sense of System F
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Martín H. Escardó's lab lunch talk

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Quantification over all types in the first universe gives a type in the first universe.
This form of impredicativity is also present in the Calculus of Constructions and the Calculus of Inductive Constructions.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Impredicativity in the sense of topos logic

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Forming powersets is allowed.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Predicativity in the sense of Aczel's CZF

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Forming powersets is not allowed.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Predicativity in the sense of MLTT

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Quantification over the types in one universe gives a type in the next universe.
This is similar to axt-005Z.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Predicativity in the sense of HoTT/UF

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: This is the same as axt-0062 since HoTT/UF is a system extending a particular MLTT with univalence and so-called higher-inductive types.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Impredicativity in the sense of HoTT/UF

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Voevodsky’s propositional resizing axiom is assumed. There are several forms of this axiom of varying strengths but they are all variations of the statement that propositional types quantifying over other types are small.
This seems to be somewhat similar to axt-0067.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Predicativity in the sense of Feferman

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Any theory that has the strength of the Feferman-Schütte ordinal or above is deemed to be impredicative.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Principle of linearity
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Personal communication with Martín H. Escardó

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The principle of linearity says that, for any two propositions P and Q, either P implies Q or Q implies P.

fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Personal communication with Martín H. Escardó

fr:mainmatter.fr:p:
Given a set X, the following are equivalent:
\mathcal {P}( X ) is a spectral frame.
X is Kuratowski-finite and has decidable equality.
X is Bishop-finite.
\mathcal {P}( X ) is a Stone frame.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Intuition on the notion of a domain
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Slide 10 of Domain Theory MGS 2007

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: In the words of Martín Escardó:

fr:blockquote.fr:p: A domain is a set of concrete finite elements together with infinite, ideal elements such that the ideal elements are characterized uniquely by their finite approximations.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: There are different ways of capturing this mathematically, to varying degrees of precision. These include continuous and algebraic dcpos.
